ENPH Question about converts Does every convert have different terms When normally are you allowed to convert to shares and is it typically at a set strike priceThe August convert had a 556 strike so those note holders have done incredibly well in under a year I think we need to wait and see what the terms are before fully understanding all the implications FYI the shares were down 13 that day quite different from what we see today foolcominvesting201808

ENPH So the last convertible happened it was Aug 15 2018 The price when it came out was around 5 and the stock dipped to 4 over the next month or so What an incredible buying opportunity that was So a 20 haircut in the short run That convert was dilutive but was done to pay off a loanshark loan and made real economic sense even at the cost of dilution Today so far the stock is not even down 5 I bought more at around 450 Will have to see what happens when the official terms of this convert are released but right now the market reaction is clearly much more positive which makes sense given that the company is growing and actually profitable

ENPH Very interesting analysis of this convert on the Yahoo board Recommend reading all of it Here is part of it It says that management sees the future value of shares being much higher than they are now 1 First point This is non dilutive In fact it is the opposite of dilutive it specifically ELIMINATES the pending dilution from last Augusts convertible note offering without creating new dilution2 Second point the company is in remarkably stronger position than they were 9 months ago and that allows the company to make a deal with the previous CN holders Often convertibles are issued by companies that are teetering That is not the case here In fact the company has done so well since last August when the first CN was issued lets call it CN1 that anyone that took a short position along with their CN has seen any hopes of profiting from that short totally disappear and at this point they are just lenders earning 4 or some leveraged multiple of that

ENPH My two centsI assume a final dilution of around 5 Of course such convertible prescriptions are also an invitation to short sellers Eric Branderiz already admitted to complex financial hedges during his time at TeslaHes a smart guy and has provoked several short squeeze on Tesla This has sometimes led to enormous price jumpsThe highlydiscounted Tennenbaum debts were recently redeemed with a similar transactionIt can be assumed that this transaction will also buy back convertible bonds from the last offer or exchange them for ordinary sharesAt the end its probably a mix of juggling with the interest rates on existing bonds which goes hand in hand with lowering them and raising capital for acquisitions expanding production capacity

ENPH Conversion of the Notes will be settled in cash shares of our common stock or a combination of cash and shares of our common stock at Enphases election Not an issue IMHO This will happen in 5 years and solely at Companys discretion More interesting nearterm is this comment Likely new converts will have interest rate lower then 4 since they are going to buyback 2023 notes with some of these funds Concurrently with the offering we intend to enter into separate and privately negotiated transactions with one or more holders of our 400 Convertible Senior Notes due 2023 the 2023 Notes to repurchase the 2023 Notes in exchange for a number of shares of our common stock approximately equal to the number of shares underlying the repurchased 2023 Notes and a cash amount to be negotiated with each holder

ENPH When the last convert happened it caused a ton of shorting and lots of downside pressure on the stock that kept it pinned around 4505 for a long time Will be interesting to see how this one affects the stock now that they are in a much stronger position In a rational world the share price SHOULD go down as this is dilutive it will lead to more shares in the float down the road That needs to be balanced against the growth this can fund and therefore future profits

ENPH I dont mind an 8 haircut when it is done to fund future growth They are doing this to make sure they can fund a second line at Flex to handle what looks like a Tsunami of demand that is coming in the next 1 years This is prudent long term financial management even if it means short term pain Remember this is still a small cap company and the 2020s could see huge growth globally They need to be ready for it Im sure they have a sense of how massive the pipeline is from all of the inquiries they are dealing with And I guarantee you these notes will sell out instantly
